t.p: Being clear on why you're creating your site and your goals is an essential first step to ensure your content and structure meet business objectives.

Visitors might not be interested in your products or services when they come to your site. They could want to learn something, improve their life, grow their business, find out more about you, etc. What great content can you offer your visitors? Why should they stay on your website?

t.p:
Your homepage is the most important page of your website. This is where visitors get their first impressions of you. An excellent homepage will encourage them to stay on your site, guide them towards your content, reinforce your company's branding and more.
Here are some pointers to help you get started.

div.p:
Find a catchy headline
Make sure anyone who visits your site understands what it’s about without having to do a lot of reading.
To do that, the visible section of your homepage (above the fold) needs to be simple and straightforward. For example, use pictures of your work, screenshots of your app, a short and catchy hook.
The Banner or Big Picture building blocks are good choices for that.

Encourage to action
Add one, and only one, call-to-action on your homepage. Your homepage is the page that gets the most visitors.
It's good practice to try to engage with your visitors on the homepage: Contact Us, Subscribe to Get More Information, Check the Catalog, etc.
Use the Newsletter subscription (from mass mailing application) or the Big button building block for that.

Add features and content
You can put more content in the intermediate section of your homepage (one or two scrolls down from the visible section), but try to keep your paragraphs easy to read and avoid 'walls of text'.
For example, use photos to help break up large areas of text by altering Text-Image and Image-Text blocks. Or if you prefer to use icons, use the Features or Feature Grid blocks.

Display social proof
Below your main banner or call-to-action, it's a good practice to put social proofs about your products or services; customer quotes, videos, photos of your products in actions, twitter quotes, etc.
You have a lot of choices for that: the References, Quotes Slider, Twitter Scroller,...

t.p:
Creating your main menu is an important and difficult stage in building your website.
It needs to be organized, so that your visitors can see all the main content you offer at a glance.
It needs to be clear, so that when they click on an item, they get the content they expected.
In fact, you need to build your navigation menu for your visitors and not for your own purposes or objectives.

div.p: The best and simplest way to start is to create a few pages and link them directly from the main menu. Just try not to go over 6 items, otherwise your main menu will be difficult to use.
As you add more pages to your website, you main menu will begin to feel overcrowded. You can regroup similar pages into a sub-menu, so they will appear under a unique drop-down menu.
Finally don't try to make all your content accessible from the main menu or the footer. Indeed, a page can also be accessible through a direct link or button, from any other page of your website.

h4.strong: With that in mind, try to define the structure of your main menu:

li.h5: 1. Your main menu items and 2. Your secondary menu items (optional):

textarea.placeholder: ex: Blog, Success stories, References, Events, Jobs

t.p: A footer, as its name implies, is located at the very bottom of your website. Because of that, your visitors won't see it immediately so it's very useful for linking pages you don't want in your main menu e.g. social media, terms and conditions, privacy terms, etc.

div.p: If you have a lot of pages in your website, you can create a small top-menu to focus on the main six pages and make all secondary pages accessible from a footer. You can have a look at the Odoo.com website, it's a great example of this type of structure.

t.p:
Launching your website is an important step.
Here is a checklist of actions to help you launch a new website efficiently:

div.p:
Initial Teaser
Before launching to the masses, it's good practice to tease around 100 of your contacts. Start with your friends, colleagues and family. Whether or not they're interested in your area of business, they will be ready to help you with feedback if you engage in a personal discussion with them.

Explain to them why you launched your new website and ask them for their views on it. Avoid using a mass survey, it's a lot more efficient to have personal discussions with everyone. If you efficiently engage them in the reviewing process, they will even help you promote your website when it's ready for the big launch.
To get an external assessment of your website, you can also submit it to peek.usertesting.com for a free evaluation of the usability of your homepage.

p.li: Send an email to all your contacts
Announce it on social media (and update your profiles): Twitter,Facebook, LinkedIn, Youtube, etc.
Update your internal documents: footer of sales order, contracts,invoices, business cards, etc.

t.p: Once you’ve launched your website, it’s time to grow your traffic.

You can do this by optimizing your referencing by search engines like Google: it's called SEO. This is the process of increasing the visibility of a website or a web page in a search engine's natural and unpaid ("organic") search results. In general, the earlier (or higher ranked on the search results page), and more frequently a site appears in the search results list, the more visitors it will receive from the search engine.
You can also place online advertisements on web pages that show results from search engine queries: this is called SEA.

div.p:
Optimize your content
Writing content that includes frequently searched-for keywords and phrases tends to increase traffic to your website.
With Odoo, you can automatically check which keywords are ranked best for a specific query, then add them in the content of your page.
To do that, simply use the Promote menu on each page of your website.

Add relevant keywords
Adding relevant keywords to a web page's meta data, including the title tag and meta description, will tend to improve the relevancy of a site's search listings, also increasing your traffic.

For example, you'll want your company name, your country/city and a few words describing your business in your homepage title so that potential customers near your location will find your website easily. WIth Odoo, this can be done easily by using the Promote menu.

Reference your images...
If you are an artist or a photographer, you can potentially bring in a lot of visitors by referencing your images so they are displayed in image search engines, like Google Images. To do that, simply add an 'Alt text' containing descriptions and keywords for relevant pictures.

... and your location too!
Millions of people use Google Maps everyday. Whether you are a restaurant or a huge business, you have no excuse not to register your location in Google Business.

Start a blog
Google loves websites which are updated often or ones where new content is added regularly. This is why starting a blog is an excellent way of improving your search ranking. If you have the time and dedication to write good articles, check out our blog application to get started.

Be linked by trusted websites
The more sites that link to your own site, the more Google trusts your site to be worthwhile:
Configure all your social media (Twitter, Facebook, LinkedIn) so that the address of your website appears on them.
Alternatively, you can write a good article about your business and publish it on an article database websites (ex: squidoo.com) or send it to a press website and your local newspapers.
Also, don't hesitate to post on other people blogs, forums, websites, but don't go overboard and post everywhere without considering whether it's a good place for you to be.

Use Google Webmaster
This tool will help you understand your search traffic and learn how users are finding your site and make optimizations to help Google better understand and represent your site. http://www.google.com/webmasters/tools/

Advertise to get the first visitors
If you have a small budget to allocate to advertising (around $100), you should start a Google Adwords campaign.

Start by looking how often people search phrases related to your business, how competitive the keywords are in AdWords, and how much it’ll cost to advertise on each keyword. All of this information will help you determine which keywords you want to use in your first campaign. Use Google Adword to do that (make sure the Advanced Options are set to your country and language).

There are three questions you should ask before deciding whether or not to advertise on a particular keyword:
Is the keyword searched for in Google? If there is no search volume, then that tells you no one is typing that phrase into Google. There is no point in advertising on keywords no one is searching for.
Is the person searching with this keyword likely to buy my product or service? Or is the person more likely to be just carrying out research with no intention of making a purchase? In other words, what is the intent of the keyword? When starting out, you’ll want to advertise on what we call “buying intent” keywords - that is, ones where the person is clearly looking to buy.
Can I afford to advertise on the keyword? If you answer yes to these 3 questions, then go ahead and position your website on these keywords.

t.p: A/B testing is the process of testing two versions of a page to see which one performs better in reaching your business objectives. For example, imagine you have an existing page (A) where you ask your customers to subscribe to your mailing list. You create a variation (B) of this page with a slightly different subscription message. Then your randomly display this page to half the visitors of your website, and after a while, you analyze the subscription statistics and see that page B performs 10% better than page A. Of course, you now decide to make B your new current page!

t.span: Note: To use those features, you need to install the Website Versioning.

t.h4: Here is a basic guide for your first A/B testing:

div.p:
1. Define what to test
Your choice of what to test will obviously depend on your goals, but should always be linked to one of your business objectives (don't spend energy improving something that brings you no ROI). Then, find the best page to test and the variation you think will bring the best results.Here are a few examples of good testing variables:
div.li: The call to action’s (i.e. the button’s) wording, size, color and placement,
Headline or product description,
Form’s length and types of fields,
Product pricing and promotional offers,
Images on landing and product pages,
Amount of text on the page (short vs. long).

div.p:
2. Create the page variation
Once you're clear on the measurable objective, the page and the variable you want to test, duplicate the page in Odoo using the 'Versions' menu and apply the modification you decided.

3. Configure a Google Analytics account
This is necessary in order to record the statistics of your test.

ul.li: Before starting, create a Google Analytics account if you don't have one yet.
Then, go to Google's developer console and connect with the Google account you created
Create a new project (this may take some time)
In the left-side menu of the project, go to APIs and auth > APIs and activate Analytics API by clicking on the Off button.
Still in the left-side menu, go to APIs and auth > Credentials and click on 'Create New Client ID'
In the pop-up window, simply enter your domain name in the first textbox (the second will complete automatically)
Then, copy the Client ID and Client Secret codes and paste them in Odoo's Google Analytics settings

div.p:
4. Create your campaign in Google Analytics
Simply follow the wizard by creating a new experiment in the Behavior > Experiments menu of Google Analytics. To learn more, take a look at their online help.

tr.td:
Know how long to run a test before giving up.
Giving up too early can cost you because you may have gotten meaningful results had you waited a little longer. Giving up too late isn’t good either, because poorly performing variations could cost you conversions and sales.

Don't test versions at different time periods.
If you test one version one week and the second the next, your results won't be accurate, or worse, wrong!

Do many A/B tests.
Chances are, your first A/B test will turn out a lemon. But don’t despair. An A/B test can have only three outcomes: no result, a negative result or a positive result. The key to optimizing conversion rates is to do a ton of A/B tests, so that all positive results add up to a huge boost to your sales and achieved goals.

Don’t conclude too early.
Wait for your test results to be significant. Take a look at the statistical confidence in Google Analytics, it should be at least 95%.

Don’t surprise regular visitors.
If you are testing a core part of your website, include only new visitors in the test. You want to avoid shocking regular visitors, especially because the variations may not ultimately be implemented.

div.span: Try to limit yourself to 1 testing variable, otherwise you won't be able to clearly interpret the results of your modifications.
